module.title: JSX Basics
module.description: Learn the syntax that powers React components

lessons.title: What is JSX?
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - JSX stands for JavaScript XML. - It allows writing HTML-like code inside JavaScript. - JSX must be compiled into standard JavaScript. - It is NOT HTML, but looks like it. --- # What is JSX? JSX stands for **JavaScript XML**. It's a syntax extension that lets you write HTML-like code in JavaScript. ## Why JSX? React uses JSX because: - It's **visual**: You can see the UI structure in your code - It's **powerful**: You can embed JavaScript expressions - It's **familiar**: If you know HTML, you're halfway there ## Basic Syntax ```jsx // This is JSX const element =

Hello, world!

; ``` Notice how it looks like HTML but lives inside JavaScript? That's JSX! ## JSX is NOT HTML While JSX looks like HTML, there are key differences: - Use `className` instead of `class` - Use `htmlFor` instead of `for` - All tags must be closed (`` not ``) - Use camelCase for attributes (`onClick`, `tabIndex`) ## Embedding Expressions Use curly braces `{}` to embed JavaScript: ```jsx const name = "React"; const element =

Hello, {name}!

; // Renders: Hello, React! ``` You can put any JavaScript expression inside the braces!

lessons.title: JSX Elements
JavaScript in JSX
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Use curly braces `{}` to embed JavaScript expressions. - Can execute math, variables, functions. - Cannot use statements like `if` or `for` inside braces. - Objects cannot be rendered directly. --- # JavaScript Expressions in JSX ## Using Curly Braces Anything inside `{}` is evaluated as JavaScript: ```jsx const price = 29.99; const quantity = 3; return

Total: {price * quantity{'}'}

; // Renders: Total: 89.97 ``` ## What You Can Put in Curly Braces - **Variables**: `{name}` - **Math**: `{2 + 2}` - **Function calls**: `{getName()}` - **Ternary operators**: `{isLoggedIn ? "Hi!" : "Login"}` - **Array methods**: `{items.length}` ## What You CANNOT Put in Curly Braces - **Statements**: No `if`, `for`, `while` directly - **Objects**: `{myObject}` won't render (objects aren't valid children) ## Conditional Rendering Use ternary operators for inline conditions: ```jsx function Greeting({ isLoggedIn }) { return (
{isLoggedIn ? (

Welcome back!

) : (

Please sign in

)}
); } ``` ## Short-circuit Evaluation Use `&&` to conditionally render: ```jsx {hasNotifications && üîî} ```

exercises.title: Your First JSX
exercises.description: Create a simple component that displays a greeting.
exercises.instructions:
Create a component called `Greeting` that returns a heading with the text "Welcome to React!".

The component should render an h1 element.
hints: Use the return keyword to return JSX

The h1 tag syntax is

text here
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if the code defines a Greeting function that returns an h1 element containing "Welcome to React!"

exercises.title: Embedding Expressions
exercises.instructions:
Create a `ProductPrice` component that:
1. Has a variable `price` set to 29.99
2. Has a variable `quantity` set to 3
3. Displays: "Total: $X" where X is price * quantity
hints: Use curly braces {} to embed JavaScript expressions in JSX
You can do math inside the curly braces
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if the code defines ProductPrice with price=29.99, quantity=3, and displays their product in a paragraph

exercises.title: Building a Card
exercises.description: Create a card component with multiple elements.
exercises.instructions:
Create a `UserCard` component that returns a div containing:
1. An h2 with "John Doe"
2. A paragraph with "Software Developer"
3. A span with the email "john@example.com"

All wrapped in a single div.
hints: Wrap multiple elements in a parent div
Use parentheses when returning multi-line JSX
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if the code returns a div with h2 "John Doe", p "Software Developer", and span "john@example.com"

exercises.title: Dynamic Greeting
exercises.description: Create a greeting with dynamic content.
exercises.instructions:
Create a `TimeGreeting` component that:
1. Has a variable `hour` set to 14
2. Displays "Good afternoon!" in a paragraph
hints: Use const to create the hour variable
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if TimeGreeting has hour=14 and displays Good afternoon

exercises.title: Navigation Menu
exercises.description: Build a simple navigation with multiple links.
exercises.instructions:
Create a `NavMenu` component with:
1. A nav element as parent
2. Three anchor tags with texts: "Home", "About", "Contact"
3. href attributes: "/", "/about", "/contact"
hints: Use nav as the wrapper element
Each a tag needs an href attribute
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if NavMenu has nav with 3 anchor tags for Home, About, Contact

exercises.title: User Profile Display
exercises.instructions:
Create a `UserProfile` component that:
1. Has variables: name = "Alice", age = 28, city = "Paris"
2. Displays: "{name}, {age} years old, from {city}" in a paragraph
hints: Use curly braces to embed each variable
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if UserProfile displays Alice, 28 years old, from Paris

exercises.title: Show if True
exercises.instructions:
Create a `Notification` component that:
1. Accepts a `hasNew` prop (boolean)
2. Shows "New notification!" only if hasNew is true
3. Uses the && operator
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if Notification uses && to conditionally show message

exercises.title: Login Status
exercises.instructions:
Create a `LoginStatus` component that:
1. Accepts `isLoggedIn` prop (boolean)
2. Shows "Welcome back!" if true
3. Shows "Please log in" if false
4. Uses ternary operator
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if LoginStatus uses ternary to show different messages
